bibl.title: Notes on Philip Showalter Hench's speech entitled "Walter Reed and the Conquest of Yellow Fever," [19--]

div1.p: This typescript deals with Hench's discussion of the recently discovered notebook containing the lab notes of Lazear and Reed. Hench credited Laura Wood with the discovery. The speech was given before the American Association of Obstetricians, Gynecologists and Abdominal Surgeons.

div1.head: Notes on Philip Showalter Hench's speech entitled "Walter Reed and the Conquest of Yellow Fever," [19--]
div1.p:
Last night at the Hotel Kahler Dr. Hench gave an address on “Walter Reed
and the Conquest of Yellow Fever,” before the American Association of Obstetricians,
Gynecologists and Abdominal Surgeons. Dr. Hench has continued his studies on the
history of this conquest having made several trips to Cuba where the discovery
of the cause of yellow fever was made. Recently, two additional bibliographic
“finds” have been made which Dr. Hench mentionedrecalled last night for the first time.
Dr. Hench has been giving some assistance to Miss Laura Wood from Washington, D. C.
whose book on the life of Walter Reed is soon to appear. In November Miss Wood,
hunting for material concerning the conquest of yellow fever, learned that there
was an unidentified notebook in the New York Academy of Medicine containing notes
on yellow fever experiments done in Cuba in 1900. It had been sold to the library
presumably as Dr. Reed's notebook. A friend of Dr. Reed's had failed to identify
the handwriting as that of Reed and the notebook had remained unidentified and with
little or no attention paid to it.

The four members of the U. S. Army Yellow Fever Commission who discovered
the cause of yellow fever were Dr. Walter Reed, head of the Board, Dr. James
Carroll, Dr. Jesse Lazear and Dr. Aristides Agramonte. During the yellow fever
experiments Dr. Lazear contracted experimental yellow fever and died, but his
carefully kept notebooks gave to Dr. Reed the chief clue which permited Dr. Reed
to extend and complete the work which incriminated the mosquito as the cause of
yellow fever. Shortly after the work was completed Dr. Reed died in 1902. Many
of his records and notebooks mysteriously disappeared from his office in Washington
and have not yet been recovered.

In 1931, someone brought to the Dr. Malloch, librarian of the New York
Academy of Medicine, a notebook which he had presumably rescued from an ash barrel.
He thought it was Dr. Reed's laboratory notebook, but when Dr. Reed's name was not
found therein the book was referred to a friend for identification. Studying the
notebook rather cursorily he did not see Dr. Reed's handwriting in the earlier parts
of the book and concluded that although the notebook obviously reported some experi-
ments carried out by the yellow fever commission it was not one of Dr. Reed's lost
notebooks. Noting the dates in the notebook, Miss Laura Wood concluded that it might
have been written by Dr. Lazear and sent to Dr. Hench three or four photostat pages.
Dr. Hench recognized the handwriting as that of Dr. Lazear, as Mrs. Lazear had given
to Dr. Hench some of Dr. Lazear's letters. Dr. Hench finally obtained a complete
photostatic copy of the notebook. The first hundred pages are in the handwriting
of Dr. Lazear and are of special historical significance because they show that on
the very day on which the announcement was made in Washington of the formation of
the Army Yellow Fever Board, Dr. Lazear visited a yellow fever patient in Havana
and collected mosquitoes from his room for examination, indicating that at that early
date Dr. Lazear was on the right track. Dr. Lazear's notes are continued until
September 13. Shortly after that he became fatally ill and died on September 25,
a martyr to science. Pages 105 to 143 are in the handwriting of Dr. Reed, giving
details of the experiments done on volunteer soldiers at Camp Lazear. These soldiers
developed experimental yellow fever as a result of being exposed to the bites of
infected mosquitoes. An interesting item was found in the one of the pages describing
an experiment on a soldier not heretofore mentioned in official or medical documents.
Dr. Hench has showed copies of the notebook to Mrs. Walter Reed and Dr. Reed's son
and daughter, also to Mrs. Lazear, the widow of Dr. Lazear. They recognized the
handwritings of Drs. Lazear and Reed and have completely authenticated the notebook.

In January, while visiting the relatives of Dr. Reed and Dr. Lazear in
Washington, Dr. Hench was invited by Mrs. Gawne and Miss Seth to visit the boyhood
home of Dr. Lazear at “Windsor” near Baltimore. In the attic were found five trunks
belonging to Dr. Lazear's mother; they had not been opened since her death many years
ago. In these trunks Dr. Hench found many photographs taken by Dr. Lazear during his
stay in Cuba, also many heretofore unpublished photographs of his boyhood, school
and college life. Of greatest interest was the finding of 140 letters written by
Dr. Lazear to his mother. Many of them described his experiences during post-
graduate medical study in Europe. Forty of them were written during Dr. Lazear's
yellow fever experiments, the last one being written on the very day when he became
fatally ill. These letters graphically illustrate Dr. Lazear's splendid
character, his eagerness to learn scientific prooftruth, his critical appraisal of
medical education in Europe and in this country, and constitute an important
new source of material for thosescholars interested in the history of the conquest of yellow
fever, one of the greatest medical discoveriesaccomplishments of all time. It is hopedplanned that this
collection of letters and other Lazear material canwill be kept intact in a medical museum in
Havana or in this country.
